template.name: Sar Template
template.description: Obtains linux system statistics collected by sa1.

item.name: sar: io: total: block read per second
item.description: Total amount of data read from the devices in blocks per second. Blocks are equivalent to sectors and therefore have a size of 512 bytes.

item.name: sar: io: total: block write per second
item.description: Total amount of data written to devices in blocks per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: page faults
item.description: Number of page faults (major + minor) made by the system per second. This is not a count of page faults that generate I/O, because some page faults can be resolved without I/O.

item.name: sar: vm: page: major page faults
item.description: Number of major faults the system has made per second, those which have required loading a memory page from disk.

item.name: sar: vm: page: freed pages
item.description: Number of pages placed on the free list by the system per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: read from disk
item.description: Total number of kilobytes the system paged in from disk per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: write from disk
item.description: Total number of kilobytes the system paged out to disk per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: scanned directly ram
item.description: Number of pages scanned directly per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: scanned kswapd
item.description: Number of pages scanned by the kswapd daemon per second.

item.name: sar: vm: page: reclaimed from cache
item.description: Number of pages the system has reclaimed from cache (pagecache and swapcache) per second to satisfy its memory demands.

item.name: sar: io: total: read tps
item.description: Total number of read requests per second issued to physical devices.

item.name: sar: io: total: tps
item.description: Total number of transfers per second that were issued to physical devices. A transfer is an I/O request to a physical device. Multiple logical requests can be combined into a single I/O request to the device. A transfer is of indeterminate size.

item.name: sar: io: total: write tps
item.description: Total number of write requests per second issued to physical devices.

item.name: sar: hugepage: usage
item.description: Percentage of total hugepages memory that has been allocated.

item.name: sar: hugepage: free
item.description: Amount of hugepages memory in kilobytes that is not yet allocated.

item.name: sar: hugepage: used
item.description: Amount of hugepages memory in kilobytes that has been allocated.

item.name: sar: power: cpu: Frequency
item.description: Instantaneous CPU clock frequency in MHz. Forced to use the slow -A key because sadf has no -m key implementation.

item.name: sar: net: ip: destination errors
item.description: The number of input datagrams discarded per second because the IP address in their IP header's destination field was not a valid address to be received at this entity. This count includes invalid addresses (e.g., 0.0.0.0) and addresses of unsupported Classes (e.g., Class E). For entities which are not IP routers and therefore do not forward datagrams, this counter includes datagrams discarded because the destination address was not a local address [ipInAddrErrors].

item.name: sar: net: ip: IN system discarded
item.description: The number of input IP datagrams per second for which no problems were encountered to prevent their continued processing, but which were discarded (e.g., for lack of buffer space) [ipInDiscards]. Note that this counter does not include any datagrams discarded while awaiting re-assembly.

item.name: sar: net: ip: header errors
item.description: The number of input datagrams discarded per second due to errors in their IP headers, including bad checksums, version number mismatch, other format errors, time-to-live exceeded, errors discovered in processing their IP options, etc. [ipInHdrErrors]

item.name: sar: net: ip: proto errors
item.description: The number of locally-addressed datagrams received successfully but discarded per second because of an unknown or unsupported protocol [ipInUnknownProtos].

item.name: sar: net: ip: OUT system discarded
item.description: The number of output IP datagrams per second for which no problem was encountered to prevent their transmission to their destination, but which were discarded (e.g., for lack of buffer space) [ipOutDiscards]. Note that this counter would include datagrams counted in fwddgm/s if any such packets met this (discretionary) discard criterion.

item.name: sar: net: tcp: attempt fails
item.description: The number of times per second TCP connections have made a direct transition to the CLOSED state from either the SYN-SENT state or the SYN-RCVD state, plus the number of times per second TCP connections have made a direct transition to the LISTEN state from the SYN-RCVD state [tcpAttemptFails].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: established resets
item.description: The number of times per second TCP connections have made a direct transition to the CLOSED state from either the ESTABLISHED state or the CLOSE-WAIT state [tcpEstabResets].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: bad checksum
item.description: The total number of segments received in error (e.g., bad TCP checksums) per second [tcpInErrs].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: sent with reset flag
item.description: The number of TCP segments sent per second containing the RST flag [tcpOutRsts].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: retransmissions
item.description: The total number of segments retransmitted per second - that is, the number of TCP segments transmitted containing one or more previously transmitted octets [tcpRetransSegs].

item.name: sar: net: ip: forwarded total
item.description: The number of input datagrams per second, for which this entity was not their final IP destination, as a result of which an attempt was made to find a route to forward them to that final destination [ipForwDatagrams].

item.name: sar: net: ip: delivered total
item.description: The total number of input datagrams successfully delivered per second to IP user-protocols (including ICMP) [ipInDelivers].

item.name: sar: net: ip: received total
item.description: The total number of input datagrams received from interfaces per second, including those received in error [ipInReceives].

item.name: sar: net: ip: dispatched total
item.description: The total number of IP datagrams which local IP user-protocols (including ICMP) supplied per second to IP in requests for transmission [ipOutRequests]. Note that this counter does not include any datagrams counted in fwddgm/s.

item.name: sar: net: sock: ipfrag queue
item.description: Number of IP fragments currently in queue.

item.name: sar: net: sock: RAW
item.description: Number of RAW sockets currently in use.

item.name: sar: net: sock: TCP TIME_WAIT
item.description: Number of TCP sockets in TIME_WAIT state.

item.name: sar: net: sock: TCP
item.description: Number of TCP sockets currently in use.

item.name: sar: net: sock: total
item.description: Total number of sockets used by the system.

item.name: sar: net: sock: UDP
item.description: Number of UDP sockets currently in use.

item.name: sar: net: tcp: active (SYN-SENT)
item.description: The number of times TCP connections have made a direct transition to the SYN-SENT state from the CLOSED state per second [tcpActiveOpens].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: segments IN
item.description: The total number of segments received per second, including those received in error [tcpInSegs]. This count includes segments received on currently established connections.

item.name: sar: net: tcp: segments OUT
item.description: The total number of segments sent per second, including those on current connections but excluding those containing only retransmitted octets [tcpOutSegs].

item.name: sar: net: tcp: passive (SYN-RCVD)
item.description: The number of times TCP connections have made a direct transition to the SYN-RCVD state from the LISTEN state per second [tcpPassiveOpens].

item.name: sar: net: udp: datagrams IN
item.description: The total number of UDP datagrams delivered per second to UDP users [udpInDatagrams].

item.name: sar: net: udp: IN errors
item.description: The number of received UDP datagrams per second that could not be delivered for reasons other than the lack of an application at the destination port [udpInErrors].

item.name: sar: net: udp: no app dst
item.description: The total number of received UDP datagrams per second for which there was no application at the destination port [udpNoPorts].

item.name: sar: net: udp: datagrams OUT
item.description: The total number of UDP datagrams sent per second from this entity [udpOutDatagrams].

item.name: sar: mem: commit %
item.description: Percentage of memory needed for current workload in relation to the total amount of memory (RAM+swap). This number may be greater than 100% because the kernel usually overcommits memory.

item.name: sar: mem: used %
item.description: Percentage of used memory.

item.name: sar: mem: active
item.description: Amount of active memory in kilobytes (memory that has been used more recently and usually not reclaimed unless absolutely necessary).

item.name: sar: mem: buffers
item.description: Amount of memory used as buffers by the kernel in kilobytes.

item.name: sar: mem: cached
item.description: Amount of memory used to cache data by the kernel in kilobytes.

item.name: sar: mem: commit
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes needed for current workload. This is an estimate of how much RAM/swap is needed to guarantee that there never is out of memory.

item.name: sar: mem: dirty
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes waiting to get written back to the disk.

item.name: sar: mem: inactive
item.description: Amount of inactive memory in kilobytes (memory which has been less recently used. It is more eligible to be reclaimed for other purposes)

item.name: sar: mem: free
item.description: Amount of free memory available in kilobytes.

item.name: sar: mem: used
item.description: Amount of used memory in kilobytes. This does not take into account memory used by the kernel itself.

item.name: sar: mem: anon pages
item.description: Amount of non-file backed pages in kilobytes mapped into userspace page tables.

item.name: sar: mem: available
item.description: Estimate of how much memory in kilobytes is available for starting new applications, without swapping. The estimate takes into account that the system needs some page cache to function well, and that not all reclaimable slab will be reclaimable, due to items being in use. The impact of those factors will vary from system to system.

item.name: sar: mem: kernel stack
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes used for kernel stack space.

item.name: sar: mem: page table
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes dedicated to the lowest level of page tables.

item.name: sar: mem: kernel cache
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use.

item.name: sar: mem: virt addr space
item.description: Amount of memory in kilobytes of used virtual address space.

item.name: sar: swp: cached %
item.description: Percentage of cached swap memory in relation to the amount of used swap space.

item.name: sar: swp: used %
item.description: Percentage of used swap space.

item.name: sar: swp: cached
item.description: Amount of cached swap memory in kilobytes. This is memory that once was swapped out, is swapped back in but still also is in the swap area (if memory is needed it doesn't need to be swapped out again because it is already in the swap area. This saves I/O).

item.name: sar: swp: free
item.description: Amount of free swap space in kilobytes.

item.name: sar: swp: used
item.description: Amount of used swap space in kilobytes.

item.name: sar: cpu: guest %
item.description: Percentage of time spent by the CPU or CPUs to run a virtual processor.

item.name: sar: cpu: idle %
item.description: Percentage of time that the CPU or CPUs were idle and the system did not have an outstanding disk I/O request. Note: On SMP machines a processor that does not have any activity at all (0.00 for every field) is a disabled (offline) processor.

item.name: sar: cpu: iowait %
item.description: Percentage of time that the CPU or CPUs were idle during which the system had an outstanding disk I/O request.

item.name: sar: cpu: IRQ %
item.description: Percentage of time spent by the CPU or CPUs to service hardware interrupts.

item.name: sar: cpu: nice %
item.description: Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the user level with nice priority.

item.name: sar: cpu: soft IRQ %
item.description: Percentage of time spent by the CPU or CPUs to service software interrupts.

item.name: sar: cpu: steal %
item.description: Percentage of time spent in involuntary wait by the virtual CPU or CPUs while the hypervisor was servicing another virtual processor.

item.name: sar: cpu: system %
item.description: Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the sys tem level (kernel). Note that this field does NOT include time spent servicing hardware or software interrupts.

item.name: sar: cpu: user %
item.description: Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the user level (application).

item.name: sar: file: dir cache unused
item.description: Number of unused cache entries in the directory cache.

item.name: sar: file: file handlers
item.description: Number of file handles used by the system.

item.name: sar: file: inode handlers
item.description: Number of inode handlers used by the system.

item.name: sar: cpu: context switches
item.description: Total number of context switches per second.

item.name: sar: cpu: tasks
item.description: Total number of tasks created per second.

item.name: sar: swp: paging IN
item.description: Total number of swap KB the system brought in per second. Originally sar displays pages. Used x4 multiplier.

item.name: sar: swp: paging OUT
item.description: Total number of swap KB the system brought out per second. Originally sar displays pages. Used x4 multiplier.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: util ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Device saturation occurs when this value is close to 100% for devices serving requests serially. But for devices serving requests in parallel, such as RAID arrays and modern SSDs, this number does not reflect their performance limits.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: average queue ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: The average queue length of the requests that were issued to the device.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: average reqsize ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: The average size (in sectors) of the requests that were issued to the device.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: await ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: The average time (in milliseconds) for I/O requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: read ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of sectors read from the device. The size of a sector is 512 bytes.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: tps ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of transfers per second that were issued to physical devices. A transfer is an I/O request to a physical device. Multiple logical requests can be combined into a single I/O request to the device. A transfer is of indeterminate size.

item_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: write ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of sectors written to the device. The size of a sector is 512 bytes.

trigger_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: intensive read ({#COUNTER})
trigger_prototype.description: Read rate on ({#COUNTER}) is more than {$SAR_IO_READ_THRESHOLD} KB.

trigger_prototype.name: sar: io: blkdev: intensive write ({#COUNTER})
trigger_prototype.description: Write rate on ({#COUNTER}) is more than {$SAR_IO_WRITE_THRESHOLD} KB.

item_prototype.name: sar: pm: fan: RPM ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Fan speed expressed in revolutions per minute

item_prototype.name: sar: pm: input: Voltage ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Voltage input expressed in Volts.

item_prototype.name: sar: pm: temp: heat ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Device temperature expressed in degrees Celsius.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: utilization ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Utilization percentage of the network interface. For half-duplex interfaces, utilization is calculated using the sum of rxkB/s and txkB/s as a percentage of the interface speed. For full-duplex, this is the greater of rxkB/S or txkB/s.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: RX data ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of kilobytes received per second.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: RX packets ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of packets received per second.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: TX data ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of kilobytes transmitted per second.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: TX packets ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of packets transmitted per second.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: collisions ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of collisions that happened per second while transmitting packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: RX dropped ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of received packets dropped per second because of a lack of space in linux buffers.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: RX errors ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of errors that happened per second while receiving packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: RX FIFO overruns ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of FIFO overrun errors that happened per second on received packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: RX frame align ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of frame alignment errors that happened per second on received packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: TX carrier ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of carrier-errors that happened per second while transmitting packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: TX dropped ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of transmitted packets dropped per second because of a lack of space in linux buffers.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: TX errors ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Total number of errors that happened per second while transmitting packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: TX FIFO overruns ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Number of FIFO overrun errors that happened per second on transmitted packets.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: err: Errors ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Sum of all interface errors.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: RX payload ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Average RX packet payload size in KB.

item_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: TX payload ({#COUNTER})
item_prototype.description: Average TX packet payload size in KB.

trigger_prototype.name: sar: net: err: ethernet errors occured on ({#COUNTER})

graph_prototype.name: sar: net: dev: RX, TX data ({#COUNTER})
sar: net: dev: RX, TX payload ({#COUNTER})

trigger.name: sar: cpu: context switch overhead
trigger.description: Context switch number is very high for this server. Think about multinode configuration for high-load services.

trigger.name: sar: cpu: CPU critical
trigger.description: Made as very sensitive event due to possible not responding situation.

trigger.name: sar: cpu: CPU high
trigger.description: Made as very sensitive event due to possible not responding situation.

trigger.name: sar: mem: memory lack
trigger.description: Overall memory utilization is normal state of the linux system. Therefore SAR_MEM_CRIT is set to 100. Change it to control some special cases.

trigger.name: sar: mem: memory overcommit
trigger.description: It may be normal behavior of Linux system configured by sysctl. But some applications may catch failure at some moment. See this variables: vm.overcommit_memory vm.overcommit_ratio
